div.head: A LIFE SKETCH.
div.p: A small, dark, cheerless room, an unshapely bed, upon which lay an unshapely remnant of humanity, whose faded eyes had wandered up and down those barren chamber walls, till every crack and crevice was as familiarly mapped out to the closed, as to the open eye. Everything dark and dingy, colorless and dreary; the propped up, worm-eaten table, and three-legged chair, and fireless hearth, and broken-paned window with its stuffing of rags; the wailing wind that whistled through them,—passing away! passing away! Mournful memories, the slow, sad procession of lost hopes trailing their tarnished, world begrimed brightness through the accumulated dust of years, palsying the tongue, filming over the eyes that still, while life lingers, roam with unspeakable and restless longings for something to rest upon beside darkness, gloom and decay.

Now and then a neighbor, poor and care-worn as herself, looked in upon the bed-ridden old woman. Short time they had, God knows, in the hurrying scramble for daily bread, to think or care for aught else; none of them knew her history; none knew how little she whose limbs had once been so daintily decked ever dreamed to lie through those weary days, and weeks, and moments, so helpless, so friendless, prisoned in from the blue sky, the sweet flowers, the green earth, biding her time to be carried out by careless hands to lie beneath them.
'Twas weary waiting—'twas weary listening for some voice that had music in it, 'twas weary looking only upon faces trouble-seamed and care-worn as her own.

The door opens gently, and the light streams in through the doorway full upon a young girl, fresh as if just from the hand of God, upon locks like vine tendrils upon the rosy cheek, and eyes of heavenly blue, upon the sweet mouth with its pitying smile—filling the dingy room with a brightness like one of God's own angels. The old woman raised herself upon her elbow and gazed upon the maiden, as one would gaze upon a flower in the desert,—upon a star in a rayless night,—upon the bright winged bird which lights for a brief moment upon the tempest-tost ship. Then—sinking back upon nerher pillow with a murmur like the home sick marihermariner in his dreams, she sighs, ah, me! how beautiful is youth!
